}} 'Latamoxef' (or 'moxalactam') is an oxacephem antibiotic usually grouped with
the cephalosporins. In oxacephems such as latamoxef, the sulfur atom of the
cephalosporin core is replaced with an oxygen atom.

Latamoxef has been associated with prolonged bleeding time, and several cases of
coagulopathy, some fatal, were reported during the 1980s.
Latamoxef is no longer available in the United States. As with other
cephalosporins with a methylthiotetrazole side chain, latamoxef causes an
antabuse reaction when mixed with alcohol. Additionally the methylthiotetrazole
side chain inhibits Î³-carboxylation of glutamic acid; this can interfere with
the actions of vitamin K.

It has been described as a third generation cephalosporin.
